docs.title: 🚀 100 Days of DevOps – Hands-On Learning Journey
docs.text:
Hi, I'm Prashant Gohel, a DevOps enthusiast documenting my structured 100 Days of DevOps challenge.

This project covers real-world DevOps tools including:

  • Linux Administration
  • Git & Version Control
  • Docker Containers
  • Kubernetes Orchestration
  • Jenkins CI/CD Pipelines
  • Ansible Automation
  • Terraform Infrastructure as Code
  • Cloud & Monitoring

docs.title: 📌 Why This Project?
docs.text:
The goal of this 100-day challenge is to:

  • Build production-ready DevOps skills
  • Document real hands-on labs
  • Share knowledge publicly
  • Help others start their DevOps journey

If you're learning DevOps, feel free to:

⭐ Star the repository 🍴 Fork it 🔁 Follow along daily 🤝 Connect with me

docs.title: Day 001: Creating a User with a Non-Interactive Shell
docs.text: The first task in the 100 Days of DevOps challenge involved creating a new user for a backup agent tool on App Server 1, requiring a non-interactive shell.

docs.title: The Task
docs.text: - The system admin team at xFusionCorp Industries needed a user named james created on one of their app servers. This user account would be used by a backup agent, so for security reasons, it shouldn't be possible for a human to log in and get a command prompt with it.

docs.title: My Solution & Command Breakdown
docs.text: - After connecting to App Server 1 using SSH, I ran a single command to accomplish the entire task.

docs.title: 1. The Creation Command
docs.text:
• This command creates the user and sets their shell at the same time.
sudo useradd james -s /sbin/nologin

Command Breakdown: * sudo: Means “Super User Do.” It lets you run commands with admin power. Since creating users needs higher permission, we use sudo to do it safely. * useradd: Linux command for adding a new user account. * james: This is the username I was asked to create. * -s: This is a flag or an "option" for Shell. It tells the useradd command which login shell the new user should have. * /sbin/nologin: A special shell that blocks the user from logging in. It’s often used for system or service accounts that don’t need direct access.

docs.title: 2. The Verification Command
docs.text:
• I used grep to check the system's user file.
grep 'james' /etc/passwd

# OUTPUT:
# james:x:1002:1002::/home/james:/sbin/nologin

Command Breakdown: * grep: Command-line tool for searching plain-text data for lines that match a regular expression or a simple string. * 'james': Search string. I was telling grep to find any line containing the word "james". * /etc/passwd: This is the file I wanted to search in. It's a system file that contains the list of all user accounts.

docs.title: Why Did I Do This? (The "What & Why")
docs.text:
This task is all about the Principle of Least Privilege. A user account should only have the permissions it absolutely needs to do its job, and nothing more.

  • Security: The backup agent doesn’t need a person to log in; it just needs permission to run tasks and own files. By giving it a non-interactive shell, we make sure no one (not even by accident) can use this account to access the server directly.
  • Automation: In DevOps, we often create service accounts for tools like Jenkins, Docker, or monitoring systems. These accounts are meant for automated programs, not humans. It’s a common and secure setup method.

docs.title: Deep Dive: What is a Non-Interactive Shell?
docs.text:
- To understand this, let’s first see what an interactive shell is. - When you log in to a Linux server, the system runs a program like /bin/bash. This shell is interactive — it shows you a prompt ($), waits for your commands, runs them, and displays the output. - A non-interactive shell is the opposite. - When a user’s shell is set to /sbin/nologin, here’s what happens: 1. Someone (or a program) tries to log in as james. 2. The system checks /etc/passwd and sees that james has /sbin/nologin as the shell. 3. It runs /sbin/nologin, which shows a message like “This account is currently not available.”. 4. Then it ends the session immediately.

  • This type of shell never gives a command prompt.
  • Think of it like a delivery gate — a robot (automated program) can drop off packages, but if a person tries to enter, the gate instantly closes.

docs.title: Exploring the Directories and Files
docs.text: Path / Command What it really represents inside the system Why it matters in real work /etc/passwd A plain text file that keeps a structured list of every user account on the machine. Each line is divided by colons, and those fields quietly describe the username, numeric user ID (UID), group ID (GID), home directory, and login shell. The UID is the internal number the system actually uses to identify a user, because Linux does not think in names — it thinks in numbers. Whenever a login happens, or a process runs as a user, the system reads this file to understand who that user is and what environment should be assigned. If something looks wrong with a user account, this is one of the first places to inspect. /etc/shadow A secured companion to /etc/passwd. It stores encrypted passwords and password aging rules. Encryption here means the real password is not stored directly; instead, a one-way hash is kept, so even if someone reads the file, they cannot reverse it into the original password. Controls authentication security. When someone tries to log in, the entered password is hashed and compared with what is stored here. Without this separation, any normal user could read everyone’s passwords. /etc/group Another structured text file that defines groups on the system. A group is simply a collection of users that share permissions to certain files or resources. Useful when managing shared access, such as giving multiple developers permission to read or write a project directory without making them system administrators. /home/james The personal working directory assigned to the user james. When the user logs in, this becomes their default location. Files created here normally belong to that user. This space isolates user data. In practical environments, logs, scripts, SSH keys, and configuration files are often kept here. If backing up user data, /home is usually a key target. /root The home directory of the superuser (root). Unlike normal users, root’s workspace is separate from /home. The root account has unrestricted privileges. Keeping its home directory separate reduces accidental exposure and keeps administrative work isolated from regular user data. /sbin/ A directory that contains system-level binaries — programs needed for administration or boot-time operations. “Binary” simply means an executable file. Historically, /sbin stored commands mainly for the root user. Tools here manage networking, disks, services, and system control. These are not typically used by normal users, but they are critical during troubleshooting. /usr/bin/ Contains most general-purpose user commands. Unlike /sbin, the programs here are commonly used by regular users. When you type commands like ls, cp, or grep, the system usually finds them here through the PATH environment variable — which is a list of directories the shell searches automatically for commands. /bin/ Traditionally held essential user commands required even before /usr is mounted during boot. During early startup or in rescue mode, this directory ensures core commands remain available. /var/log/ Stores log files generated by the system and services. A log file is simply a chronological record of events. When debugging server issues, this directory becomes extremely important. For example, service failures, authentication problems, or kernel warnings are recorded here. /sbin/nologin A special program used as a user’s login shell to intentionally prevent interactive login. When this is set as the shell, the system refuses terminal access for that account. Commonly assigned to service accounts — accounts created only to run applications. This improves security because it blocks direct login attempts. useradd james Command used to create a new user. Internally, it adds entries into /etc/passwd, /etc/shadow, and possibly /etc/group. In real projects, when onboarding a new team member, this command establishes their identity in the system. usermod -aG developers james Modifies an existing user. The -aG flag means append the user to a supplementary group without removing them from others. A group defines shared permissions. Useful when temporarily granting access to a shared resource without giving full administrative rights. id james Displays the numeric UID, primary group, and supplementary groups of the user. Quickly verifies whether permission issues are caused by missing group membership. chown james:developers file.txt Changes file ownership. “Ownership” means which user and group control access to a file. Essential when fixing permission problems after copying files or restoring backups. chmod 750 script.sh Adjusts permission bits. The numbers represent read (4), write (2), execute (1). So 750 means full access for owner, limited access for group, no access for others. Directly controls who can read, modify, or run a file. In server environments, misconfigured permissions are a common cause of security risks.

docs.title: Day 002: Creating a User with an Expiry Date
docs.text: In the 100 Days of DevOps challenge, I managed temporary user access for a limited-time developer, 'anita', by creating her account and ensuring it would expire on a specific date.

docs.title: The Task
docs.text: A developer named anita needed temporary access to App Server 3. 1. Create a user account named anita. 2. Set the account to expire on January 28, 2024.

docs.title: My Solution & Command Breakdown
docs.text: - After connecting to App Server 3 via SSH, I used two commands: one to create the user and another to verify the expiry date was set correctly.

docs.title: 1. The Creation Command
docs.text:
• This command creates the user anita and sets the account expiration date in a single step.
sudo useradd anita --expiredate 2024-01-28

Command Breakdown: * --expiredate: This option is used with useradd to set the date when the user account should automatically expire (get disabled). The date must be written in the format YYYY-MM-DD.

docs.title: 2. The Verification Command
docs.text:
• To confirm the expiry date was applied, I used the chage (change age) utility.

sudo chage -l anita

# OUTPUT:
# Account expires                       : Jan 28, 2024
This command displayed all the aging policies for the anita account.

Command Breakdown: * chage: Command-line tool for viewing and modifying user password and account aging information. * -l: The "list" flag, which instructs chage to display the current settings for a user.

docs.title: Why Did I Do This? (The "What & Why")
docs.text:
This task shows how security policies can be automated. In real situations, many contractors or temporary workers need short-term access. Manually remembering to disable all those accounts is time-consuming and easy to forget.

  • Better Security: Temporary accounts can become dangerous if left active after someone leaves — these forgotten or “ghost” accounts are big security risks. Setting an expiry date makes sure access ends automatically, keeping the system safe.
  • Less Mannual Work: I don’t have to set reminders or create support tickets to disable accounts later. The system does it for me, which follows a key DevOps idea — automate repetitive tasks.
  • Compliance Made Ease: Many companies have rules about how long temporary users can have access. Using --expiredate helps enforce those rules automatically.

docs.title: Deep Dive: How Account Expiry Works
docs.text:
In Linux, when an account expires, it means the account is disabled, not deleted.

When the system date reaches 2024-01-28, here’s what happens to the anita account: - Disabled → Anita can’t log in anymore; every login attempt fails. - Not Deleted → Her files and home folder (/home/anita) still exist, and her entry remains in /etc/passwd.

This is actually the ideal behavior — the account is blocked, but her data stays safe for auditing or record-keeping. If needed, an admin can easily re-enable the account later by updating or removing the expiry date.

👉 Note: This is not the same as password expiry. Password expiry only forces the user to change their password — it doesn’t disable their account.

docs.title: Exploring the Commands Used
docs.text: | Command / Option | What it really controls internally | Why it becomes important in real systems | | ------------------------------ | ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | chage username | Modifies password aging rules stored in /etc/shadow. That file contains extra fields beyond the hashed password — it also stores the last password change date (as days since Jan 1, 1970), maximum valid days, minimum required days, warning period, and inactivity limit. chage updates those numeric fields safely instead of editing the file manually. | When enforcing password policies on servers — especially shared or production machines — this becomes critical. It ensures users rotate passwords on time and prevents stale accounts from staying active indefinitely. | | chage -l username | Reads and interprets the aging fields from /etc/shadow and converts those raw numbers into human-readable dates. Instead of showing “19876”, it shows an actual expiry date. | Very useful for auditing. During security reviews, this quickly tells whether a user’s password expires, when it was last changed, and whether an account is locked due to inactivity. | | chage -M 90 username | Sets the maximum number of days a password remains valid. After 90 days from the last change, the system forces a password update during login. | Common corporate policy is 60–90 days. This enforces compliance without depending on users to remember policies. | | chage -m 7 username | Sets the minimum number of days before a password can be changed again. If set to 7, the user cannot change it again for a week. | Prevents users from bypassing expiration rules by immediately changing the password multiple times to reuse an old one. | | chage -W 14 username | Defines how many days before expiration the system starts warning the user during login. | Gives users time to update passwords before forced lockout, reducing operational disruptions. | | chage -I 30 username | Sets an inactivity period. After a password expires, if it remains unchanged for 30 additional days, the account becomes inactive. “Inactive” means login is blocked until an administrator intervenes. | Useful when accounts belong to employees who left but weren’t removed. It automatically disables neglected accounts after expiry. | | chage -E 2026-12-31 username | Sets a fixed account expiration date. After this calendar date, the entire account becomes unusable regardless of password validity. | Very practical for contract employees, interns, or temporary service accounts. Access stops automatically after the agreed date. | | passwd -e username | Forces immediate password expiration by updating the last-change field to zero. At next login, the user must set a new password. | Used after a password reset or security incident to ensure the user creates their own secret password. | | passwd -S username | Displays current password status summary, including whether it is locked, active, or expired. | Quick health check without listing all aging details. | | usermod -L username | Locks the account by placing an exclamation mark before the password hash in /etc/shadow. This prevents authentication because the hash no longer matches any valid password. | Immediate way to disable access without deleting the account — important for incident response. | | usermod -U username | Unlocks a previously locked account by restoring the usable password hash. | Allows controlled reactivation of user access. |

docs.title: Day 003: Disabling Direct Root SSH Login
docs.text: On Day 3, my DevOps journey involved a crucial server hardening task, disabling root user login via SSH , which is a crucial step for securing a new server across all three app servers.

docs.title: The Task
docs.text: - Following a security audit, I was tasked with disabling direct SSH root login on all app servers in Datacenter. The goal was to prevent anyone from connecting to the servers using the username root.

docs.title: My Solution & Command Breakdown
docs.text: - I had to repeat the same process on each of the three servers. The process involved editing a single configuration file and then restarting the SSH service.

docs.title: 1. Editing the SSH Configuration File
docs.text:
• First, I connected to each server via SSH using my personal user account. Then, I used a text editor (vi) with sudo to modify the main SSH daemon configuration file.
sudo vi /etc/ssh/sshd_config

Command Breakdown: * vi: The text editor I used to make the change. * /etc/ssh/sshd_config: Configuration file for the SSH server (the d in sshd stands for daemon, which is a background service).

Inside this file, I searched for the line containing PermitRootLogin. I found it commented out and set to yes: #PermitRootLogin yes. I removed the # and changed yes to no. The final line looked like this:

PermitRootLogin no

docs.title: 2. Restarting the SSH Service
docs.text:
Configuration changes to a service are not applied until the service is restarted. I used systemctl to do this.

sudo systemctl restart sshd

Command Breakdown: * systemctl: Command-Line-Tool for managing services (daemons) in modern Linux distributions. * restart: The action I wanted systemctl to perform. * sshd: The name of the SSH service I wanted to restart.

After completing these two steps on stapp01, I exited and repeated the exact same process on stapp02 and stapp03.

docs.title: Why Did I Do This? (The "What & Why")
docs.text:
Turning off direct root login is one of the most basic but powerful security steps in Linux. Here’s why:

  • Stops Brute-Force Attacks → The username root is public knowledge, so hackers and bots constantly try to guess its password. By disabling root login, I remove that target completely — now an attacker must first guess a valid username and the password.

  • Adds Accountability → Instead of everyone using the same root account, each admin logs in with their own user and uses sudo for admin actions. Every sudo command is recorded, showing who did what and when, making tracking and auditing easy.

  • Encourages Safety → Working as a normal user helps prevent accidental damage. You have to type sudo to gain admin rights, which forces you to stop and think before running risky commands.

docs.title: Deep Dive: The PermitRootLogin Directive
docs.text:
The PermitRootLogin setting in the sshd_config file decides if the root user can log in via SSH. Key options:

  • yes → Allows root to log in directly using a password (often default, but risky).

  • no → Blocks root login completely. This is the safest and what I used.

  • prohibit-password (or without-password) → Root can log in only with SSH keys, not a password. Safer than yes, but not as strict as no.

For security, no is the best choice.

docs.title: Exploring the Files and Commands
docs.text: File / Command What it really controls internally Why it matters in real environments /etc/ssh/sshd_config This is the primary configuration file read by the SSH daemon process (sshd) when it starts. A daemon is simply a background service that waits for requests. Each directive inside this file changes how the server accepts remote connections — for example, which port it listens on, whether password authentication is allowed, whether root login is permitted, and which users or groups are allowed or denied. When sshd starts, it parses this file line by line and builds its runtime behavior from it. This file directly defines the attack surface of a Linux server. Changing Port 22 to another value does not increase cryptographic security, but it reduces automated scan noise. Setting PasswordAuthentication no forces key-based login, which relies on asymmetric cryptography — a method where a public key encrypts and a private key decrypts — making brute-force password attacks ineffective. Misconfiguring this file can either weaken security or completely block remote access. sshd -t Tests the syntax of /etc/ssh/sshd_config without restarting the service. It checks whether the configuration is valid and whether directives are recognized. Prevents accidental lockout. Before restarting SSH on a remote server, running this ensures you won’t break connectivity due to a syntax mistake. ss -tulnp Displays listening ports and associated processes. -t means TCP, -u means UDP, -l shows listening sockets, -n avoids DNS resolution, and -p shows process IDs. After modifying the SSH port, this confirms whether sshd is actually listening on the new port. systemctl A command-line interface to systemd, which is the service manager responsible for starting, stopping, and supervising background services. Instead of manually launching daemons, systemd tracks their state and ensures they follow defined startup rules. Modern Linux distributions rely on systemd to maintain service reliability. It centralizes process control and boot-time dependency management. systemctl restart sshd Stops and immediately starts the SSH daemon again, forcing it to reload the configuration from disk. Required after changing sshd_config. Restart ensures new rules apply. However, restarting over an active SSH session should be done carefully. systemctl reload sshd Signals the service to reload configuration without fully stopping it. Internally, it sends a SIGHUP signal, which tells the daemon to re-read its config gracefully. Safer than restart because active sessions usually remain unaffected. Useful when adjusting authentication settings. systemctl status sshd Shows whether the service is active, failed, or inactive, along with recent log entries from journalctl. During troubleshooting, this immediately reveals startup errors or port conflicts. systemctl enable sshd Creates symbolic links in systemd’s boot sequence directories so that SSH starts automatically at boot. A symbolic link is a pointer to another file. Essential for production servers. Without enabling, SSH would not start after reboot, cutting off remote access. systemctl disable sshd Removes the boot-time symbolic links so the service does not auto-start. Useful in hardened or containerized environments where SSH access is intentionally restricted. journalctl -u sshd Reads logs stored by systemd’s journal specifically for the SSH service. The journal is a centralized binary logging system. When authentication fails or configuration breaks, this gives precise error messages, such as “invalid user” or “bad configuration option.” /etc/ssh/ssh_config Client-side SSH configuration file. Unlike sshd_config, which controls the server, this file defines how the SSH client behaves when connecting outward. Useful for defining default keys, custom ports, or aliases for frequently accessed servers.

docs.title: Day 004: Setting Executable Permissions on a Script
docs.text: I was tasked with making a shell script executable, as the system required the necessary permissions to run the new backup script.

docs.title: The Task
docs.text: The task involved granting executable permissions to a bash script named xfusioncorp.sh on App Server 2 and ensuring all system users could execute it.

docs.title: My Solution & Command Breakdown
docs.text: - After connecting to App Server 2, I first checked the existing permissions and then used a single command to change them.

docs.title: 1. The Verification Command (Before)
docs.text:
• I used ls -l to get a detailed listing of the file.
ls -l /tmp/xfusioncorp.sh

# OUTPUT:
# -rw-r--r-- ...   -> confirmed that no one had execute (`x`) permissions.

docs.title: 2. The Permission Change Command
docs.text:
I used the chmod (change mode) command to add the necessary permissions.

sudo chmod a+x /tmp/xfusioncorp.sh

Command Breakdown: * chmod: The main command used to change file permissions. * a+x: A symbolic way to add execute permission: * a: all users (owner, group, others) * +: add permission * x: execute permission

docs.title: 3. The Verification Command (After)
docs.text:
I ran the ls -l command again to confirm my change was successful. 

ls -l /tmp/xfusioncorp.sh

# OUTPUT:
# -rwxr-xr-x ...

docs.title: Why Did I Do This? (The "What & Why")
docs.text:
This task is all about telling the operating system that a file is not just data to be read, but a program that can be run.

  • Security: By default, new files aren’t executable. This prevents random or downloaded files from running automatically, keeping the system safe. Linux makes sure only trusted scripts or programs can run.

  • Operational Need: Automation scripts need execute permission to work. In this case, the backup system (and admins testing it) must be able to run the script. Without +x, the system would block it with a “Permission Denied” error, even if the script is correct.

docs.title: Deep Dive: Understanding Linux File Permissions
docs.text:
A permission string like -rwxr-xr-x has four parts: - File Type → The first character shows the type: - = regular file, d = directory. - Owner Permissions → Next three (rwx) are for the owner: read, write, execute. - Group Permissions → Next three (r-x) are for the group: read and execute, but no write. - Other Permissions → Last three (r-x) are for everyone else: read and execute, but no write.

Two common ways to set permissions:

  • Symbolic Notation → Human-readable like a+x (all users add execute), u+x(user add execute), g+w (group add write), o-r (others remove read).
  • Octal/ Numeric Notation → Each permission has a number: read=4, write=2, execute=1. Add them for each category:
  • Owner rwx = 4+2+1 = 7
  • Group r-x = 4+0+1 = 5
  • Others r-x = 4+0+1 = 5 So sudo chmod 755 /tmp/xfusioncorp.sh does the same as setting rwxr-xr-x.

docs.title: Exploring the Commands Used
docs.text:
This task introduced me to two of the most frequently used commands in Linux.

Command What actually happens inside the system Why it becomes powerful in real work ls -l Displays files in long listing format. The first column shows the file type and permission bits. The permission string like -rwxr-xr-- is not random — the first character tells whether it is a regular file (-), directory (d), or link (l). The next nine characters are grouped into three sets: owner, group, and others. Each set shows read (r), write (w), and execute (x) access. After permissions, it shows link count, owner name, group name, file size in bytes, and last modification time. When troubleshooting “Permission denied,” this is the first command to run. It reveals who owns the file and what access level exists. Without seeing these details, permission debugging becomes guesswork. stat file.txt Shows deeper metadata of a file, including numeric mode (like 0755), inode number, and timestamps for access, modification, and change. The inode is the internal data structure where Linux stores file metadata on disk. Helpful when analyzing file behavior in detail, especially when permissions appear correct but something still fails. chmod 755 script.sh Changes permission bits numerically. The number 7 means read (4) + write (2) + execute (1). So 755 gives full access to owner (7), and read + execute (5) to group and others. Linux stores these bits as part of the file’s metadata. Common when preparing scripts for execution. Without the execute bit, even a correct script cannot run. chmod u+x script.sh Symbolic mode. Instead of numbers, it modifies specific categories. u means user (owner), g means group, o means others, and a means all. +x adds execute permission. Safer when you don’t want to accidentally overwrite all permission bits. It modifies only what you specify. chmod g-w file.txt Removes write permission from the group while leaving other bits unchanged. Used when tightening shared directory permissions without affecting ownership. chmod -R 750 project_dir/ Applies permission changes recursively (-R) to all files and subdirectories. Essential when securing an entire project folder at once. Must be used carefully, as it affects many files. umask Shows or sets the default permission mask applied when new files are created. A mask subtracts permission bits from the default 666 (files) or 777 (directories). Controls default security posture. For example, a umask 027 ensures newly created files are not accessible to “others.” getfacl file.txt Displays Access Control Lists (ACLs). ACLs are extended permission rules beyond the traditional owner/group/others model. Useful in advanced environments where multiple specific users need different access levels. setfacl -m u:john:rwx file.txt Modifies ACL to give a specific user full access regardless of primary group. Helps when standard permission bits are too limited for complex collaboration. chown james:dev file.txt Changes file ownership to user james and group dev. Ownership determines who has primary control. Without correct ownership, permission changes may not work as expected. find . -type f -perm 0777 Searches for files with overly permissive access. -perm 0777 checks numeric permission bits. Useful in security audits to detect risky files that allow universal access.

docs.title: Day 005: Installing SELinux and Handling Unexpected Issues
docs.text: On Day 5, a server was prepared for a new security implementation using SELinux, requiring installation of necessary tools and disabling SELinux in its configuration file.

docs.title: The Task
docs.text: - The task involved installing SELinux packages, permanently disabling SELinux by modifying its configuration file, and ensuring the change only takes effect after the next reboot.

docs.title: 1. Install the Correct Packages
docs.text:
• The key was to identify the exact package names for this version of Linux.
sudo yum install policycoreutils selinux-policy -y

Command Breakdown: * sudo yum install -y: Command to install software with admin rights and auto-confirm prompts. * policycoreutils: Provides essential tools to manage SELinux, like sestatus and setenforce. * selinux-policy: Contains the rules (policy) that SELinux enforces. This package is required for SELinux to work.

docs.title: 2. Configure SELinux to be Disabled
docs.text:
Next, I edited the configuration file to disable SELinux on the next boot.

sudo vi /etc/selinux/config

# Inside the file, I changed the `SELINUX` directive to `disabled`:
# SELINUX=disabled

docs.title: My Troubleshooting Journey
docs.text: I faced two main problems while setting up SELinux:

docs.title: Hurdle #1: "Packages Not Installed" Error
docs.text:
• I first tried sudo yum install -y policycoreutils-python, which failed: “Unable to find a match.”
  • Lesson: Package names differ across Linux versions. The -python version exists in older systems (like CentOS 7), but in newer systems, the tools are bundled differently. I also needed selinux-policy for the validation script.

docs.title: Hurdle #2: Empty Configuration File
docs.text:
• I found /etc/selinux/config was empty. An empty file makes the system default to enforcing mode, causing task failure.
  • Solution: I created the file from scratch using a here document:

sudo bash -c 'cat > /etc/selinux/config <<EOF
# This file controls the state of SELinux on the system.
SELINUX=disabled
SELINUXTYPE=targeted
EOF'
This writes everything between EOF markers into the file in one go — fast, reliable, and non-interactive.

docs.title: Why Did I Do This? (The "What & Why")
docs.text:
This task simulates a very common real-world scenario.

  • What is SELinux? It’s a security layer beyond regular user/group permissions. It controls exactly what programs can do. For example, it can stop Apache from accessing users’ home files, even if normal permissions allow it.
  • Why Install It? To use SELinux, you need the tools (policycoreutils) to manage it and the rules (selinux-policy) to enforce actions.
  • Why Disable It (Temporarily)? SELinux is powerful but tricky. Admins often disable it while installing new apps or troubleshooting, so things work first. Later, they can re-enable it with proper policies without breaking the system.

docs.title: Deep Dive: The /etc/selinux/config File
docs.text:
This file controls SELinux at boot. The key setting is SELINUX=, which can be:

  • enforcing: Default and most secure. SELinux blocks any action that breaks its rules.
  • permissive: SELinux is active but only logs warnings instead of blocking actions. Good for testing policies.
  • disabled: SELinux is fully off. No policies are loaded. This is what I set it to.

docs.title: Key Takeaways from This Task
docs.text: | File / Command | What it actually contains internally | Why it matters in real systems | | ----------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | /etc/os-release | A small text file that stores identification metadata about the operating system. It contains key–value pairs like NAME=, VERSION=, ID=, and VERSION_ID=. These values are not for humans only — they are primarily meant for programs and scripts to reliably detect which Linux distribution is running. | When writing automation scripts, installation scripts, or Ansible playbooks, detecting the OS correctly is critical. Different distributions use different package managers (like apt for Debian-based systems or yum/dnf for Red Hat-based systems). Reading this file allows scripts to adjust behavior safely. | | cat /etc/os-release | Displays the file contents directly. Since the file is simple text, it can be viewed with cat, less, or any text editor. | Quick way to confirm OS type during troubleshooting or when logging into a new server. | | grep "^ID=" /etc/os-release | Extracts only the distribution ID field. grep searches for matching patterns, and ^ anchors the match to the beginning of the line. | Useful inside shell scripts to branch logic based on distribution. | | source /etc/os-release | Loads the file into the current shell environment. Because it follows KEY=value format, it can be interpreted directly by the shell. After sourcing, variables like $ID and $VERSION_ID become available. | Very practical in automation scripts. Instead of parsing manually, you can directly reference environment variables. | | /etc/issue | Another identification file that usually prints a short system banner before login. It is designed for display purposes rather than programmatic detection. | Helps identify the server before login, but less reliable for scripting. | | hostnamectl | Shows system hostname along with OS and kernel details by querying systemd. | Gives combined identity information in one structured output, especially useful on modern systems using systemd. | | uname -r | Shows the running kernel version. The kernel is the core component of Linux that interacts directly with hardware. | Important when troubleshooting compatibility issues or checking whether a security patch is applied. |

docs.title: Day 006: Automation with Cron Jobs
docs.text: Today I learned about automation by implementing cron jobs to set up a scheduled task for all application servers. This exercise highlighted the importance of automating routine tasks like backups, system checks, and report generation. The process involved installing a service, ensuring it was running, and configuring the scheduled job.

docs.title: The Task
docs.text: - The goal was to establish a cron job on three Nautilus app servers, installing the 'cronie' package, enabling the 'crond' service, and adding a cron job for the 'root' user every 5 minutes, executing the command 'echo hello > /tmp/cron_text'.

docs.title: My Step-by-Step Solution
docs.text: - I performed the following sequence of actions on each of the three app servers.

docs.title: Step 1: Install and Start the Cron Service
docs.text:
• First, I needed to ensure the cron daemon was installed and running. 
    # Install the necessary package
sudo yum install -y cronie

# Start the service for the current session
sudo systemctl start crond

# Enable the service so it starts automatically on reboot
sudo systemctl enable crond

docs.title: Step 2: Add the Cron Job for the root User
docs.text:
• To edit the crontab for a specific user, I used crontab -e. To edit it for the root user, I had to use sudo. 
    sudo crontab -e

# This opened a text editor (vi). I pressed `i` to enter insert mode and added the required line:
*/5 * * * * echo hello > /tmp/cron_text

# Then I pressed `Esc`, and typed `:wq` to save and quit.

docs.title: Step 3: Verification
docs.text:
The most important part is making sure the job is scheduled and works correctly. * Check the schedule: I listed the cron jobs for the root user to ensure my entry was saved. 

sudo crontab -l
* Check the output: I waited for up to 5 minutes for the job to execute. Then, I checked the output file. 
cat /tmp/cron_text
Seeing the word "hello" in this file was the final confirmation of success.

I repeated these three steps on all app servers to complete the task.

docs.title: Why Did I Do This? (The "What & Why")
docs.text: - cron: The classic Linux tool for scheduling tasks. The background service that runs it is called crond - cronie: The package on modern Red Hat-based systems (like CentOS) that provides crond and the crontab command. - crontab: Stands for cron table. It’s a file listing scheduled jobs. Each user can have their own crontab. Editing with crontab -e is safe because it checks syntax before saving. - Running as root: Some tasks, like backups or updates, need admin privileges. Using sudo crontab -e edits the root user’s crontab, letting these tasks run with full permissions.

docs.title: Deep Dive: Decoding the Cron Schedule
docs.text:
The */5 * * * * part can look cryptic, but it follows a simple pattern. There are five fields, representing different units of time.

.---------------- minute (0 - 59)
|  .------------- hour (0 - 23)
|  |  .---------- day of month (1 - 31)
|  |  |  .------- month (1 - 12)
|  |  |  |  .---- day of week (0 - 6) (Sunday to Saturday)
|  |  |  |  |
* * * * * <-- command to be executed
- A * means "every". - */5 in the minute field means "every 5th minute".

So, */5 * * * * translates to: "At every 5th minute, of every hour, on every day-of-month, of every month, on every day-of-week."

docs.title: Common Pitfalls
docs.text:
Editing the Wrong Crontab: If you forget sudo, crontab -e edits your personal crontab (e.g., user tony) instead of root’s. Make sure you use sudo for system-level tasks.

Path Issues: Cron runs in a minimal environment. Always use absolute paths for commands and files (e.g., /bin/echo instead of echo) to avoid “command not found” errors.

docs.title: Exploring the Commands Used
docs.text: | Command | What is happening behind the scenes | Why it matters in real operations | | ----------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ | | sudo yum install -y cronie | Uses the yum package manager (Yellowdog Updater, Modified) to install the cronie package, which provides the cron daemon. A package manager downloads software from configured repositories, resolves dependencies (required supporting packages), and installs binaries and service files into the system. The -y flag automatically answers “yes” to confirmation prompts. | On minimal server installations, cron may not be present. Installing cronie ensures scheduled task capability exists. Automation without cron is incomplete because many maintenance tasks depend on scheduling. | | sudo systemctl start crond | Instructs systemd (the service manager) to start the crond daemon immediately. A daemon is a background process that waits and performs tasks automatically. Once started, crond continuously checks crontab schedules and executes commands at the specified times. | Starting the service ensures scheduled jobs begin running in the current session. If not started, even configured cron jobs will never execute. | | sudo systemctl enable crond | Creates symbolic links inside systemd’s boot configuration so that crond starts automatically during system boot. Enabling does not start the service immediately; it prepares it for future reboots. | Essential for persistence. Without enabling, cron jobs stop working after a server restart, which is risky in production environments. | | systemctl status crond | Shows whether the cron service is active, failed, or inactive, along with recent logs. | Useful to confirm that the scheduler is actually running and not silently failing. | | sudo crontab -e | Opens the root user’s crontab file in a text editor. The crontab is a schedule table where each line defines a time pattern followed by a command. Cron reads these entries and executes them when the time matches. | Used to create system-wide administrative tasks such as backups, log cleanup, or service health checks. Editing as root allows high-privilege tasks. | | sudo crontab -l | Lists the current root crontab entries. | Verifies scheduled jobs without modifying them. Helpful during auditing or debugging. | | crontab -e | Edits the current logged-in user’s crontab instead of root’s. | Recommended for application-level tasks to avoid running everything as root unnecessarily. | | cat /tmp/cron_text | Displays the contents of a file generated by a cron job. The /tmp directory is a temporary storage area cleared periodically or at reboot depending on configuration. | Simple verification step to confirm whether a scheduled task executed correctly and produced output. | | grep CRON /var/log/messages | Searches system logs for cron-related execution messages. Logs record events generated by system services. | Useful when a cron job fails silently or does not produce expected output. | | crontab -r | Removes the current user’s crontab file completely. | Must be used carefully, but helpful when resetting scheduled tasks. | | /etc/crontab | A system-wide cron configuration file that includes an additional field specifying which user should run each job. | Useful for central administration where tasks must run under different user accounts. |

docs.title: Day 007: Automation with Password-less SSH
docs.text: The task involved setting up an infrastructure for automation by configuring password-less SSH access from a central jump host to all app servers. This was crucial to prevent automated scripts from failing when connecting to remote servers. The task introduced public key authentication, a secure, script-friendly alternative to traditional password-based logins.

docs.title: The Task
docs.text: My goal was to configure the thor user on the jump_host to be able to SSH into all three app servers without needing a password. The connections had to be made to the specific sudo user on each server: - thor@jump_host -> tony@stapp01 - thor@jump_host -> steve@stapp02 - thor@jump_host -> banner@stapp03

docs.title: My Step-by-Step Solution
docs.text: - The entire process was performed as the thor user on the jump_host.

docs.title: Step 1: Generate an SSH Key Pair
docs.text:
• First, I needed to create a unique identity for the thor user. This is done by generating a pair of cryptographic keys: one private, one public. 
    # Run from the jump_host as user thor
ssh-keygen -t rsa
    I pressed Enter three times to accept the default file location (~/.ssh/id_rsa), to set no passphrase (which is essential for automation), and to confirm.

docs.title: Step 2: Copy the Public Key to Each App Server
docs.text:
• Next, I distributed my public key to each of the target servers. The ssh-copy-id command is built specifically for this and is the most reliable method. It automatically appends the key to the ~/.ssh/authorized_keys file on the remote server and sets the correct file permissions.

I was prompted for each user's password one final time to authorize the key transfer. 

# Copy key to App Server 1
ssh-copy-id tony@stapp01

# Copy key to App Server 2
ssh-copy-id steve@stapp02

# Copy key to App Server 3
ssh-copy-id banner@stapp03

docs.title: Step 3: Verification
docs.text:
• The final and most important step was to test the password-less connection to each server. 
    ssh tony@stapp01
# I was logged in instantly without a password.
exit

ssh steve@stapp02
# Logged in instantly.
exit

ssh banner@stapp03
# Logged in instantly.
exit

docs.title: Why Did I Do This? (The "What & Why")
docs.text: - Password-less is still secure: Instead of a password that could be guessed or stolen, this method uses long, complex cryptographic keys. - Public Key Authentication: Works like a lock and key: - Private Key (~/.ssh/id_rsa): Your secret key, kept on the machine you connect from (never shared). - Public Key (~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub): The lock, copied to any machine you want to access. - Automation Needs: Scripts must run without human input. Passwords would stop a script on each server, but public key authentication lets scripts connect automatically.

docs.title: Deep Dive: How Public Key Authentication Works
docs.text: It’s a secure challenge-response process — no passwords are sent over the network. 1. Connection Request → My jump_host contacts stapp01, saying: “I’m user tony and want to log in with a public key.” 2. The Challenge → stapp01 finds my public key in ~/.ssh/authorized_keys, creates a random one-time message, encrypts it with my public key, and sends it back. 3. The Response → Only my private key (on the jump_host) can decrypt this message. My machine decrypts it. 4. Proof of Identity → My jump_host sends the decrypted message back to stapp01. 5. Access Granted → stapp01 confirms the message was decrypted correctly, proving I own the private key. Access is granted without ever using a password.

docs.title: Common Pitfalls
docs.text: - Setting a Passphrase: Adding a passphrase is secure for personal use, but breaks automation. Scripts can’t enter a passphrase, so service accounts must leave it empty. - Incorrect Permissions: SSH is strict. If the .ssh folder or authorized_keys file has wrong permissions, the keys won’t work. Using ssh-copy-id fixes this automatically. - Copying the Wrong Key: Never copy your private key (id_rsa). Only the public key (id_rsa.pub) should be shared.

docs.title: Exploring the Commands Used
docs.text: | Command | What actually happens internally | Why it matters in real environments | | ---------------------------------- | -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | ssh-keygen -t rsa | Generates an asymmetric cryptographic key pair. “Asymmetric” means two related keys are created: a public key (shared) and a private key (kept secret). RSA (Rivest–Shamir–Adleman) is an algorithm based on mathematical properties of large prime numbers. The private key is stored locally (usually in ~/.ssh/), and the public key is saved as a .pub file. | Forms the foundation of passwordless and secure SSH login. Instead of transmitting passwords over the network, authentication is done using cryptographic challenge–response verification, which is significantly more secure than plain passwords. | | ssh-keygen -t ed25519 | Creates a key pair using the Ed25519 algorithm. This is a modern elliptic-curve cryptography method, meaning it relies on algebraic structures over finite fields rather than prime factorization like RSA. | Recommended today for better performance and stronger security with smaller key sizes. Many modern systems prefer this over RSA. | | ssh-keygen -b 4096 -t rsa | Generates an RSA key with a 4096-bit length. The bit length represents the size of the cryptographic key — larger sizes increase resistance to brute-force attacks but also slightly increase computational cost. | Used in environments requiring higher security policies. | | ssh-copy-id user@host | Connects to the remote server over SSH using password authentication once. It appends your public key to the remote user’s ~/.ssh/authorized_keys file. It also ensures proper directory permissions (700 for .ssh and 600 for authorized_keys). | Simplifies key distribution. Manual copying can lead to permission mistakes, and SSH will refuse key authentication if permissions are too open. | | cat ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub | Displays the public key content. A public key is safe to share because it cannot derive the private key. | Used when manually pasting a key into a remote system or cloud console. | | chmod 700 ~/.ssh | Ensures the .ssh directory has secure permissions. Only the owner can read, write, or enter it. | SSH refuses to use keys if directory permissions are too permissive, as that could expose private credentials. | | chmod 600 ~/.ssh/authorized_keys | Restricts the authorized keys file to be readable and writable only by the owner. | Prevents other users on the system from viewing or modifying allowed public keys. | | ssh -i ~/.ssh/id_rsa user@host | Connects using a specific private key file instead of the default key. | Useful when managing multiple keys for different servers or clients. | | eval "$(ssh-agent -s)" | Starts the SSH authentication agent. The agent holds private keys in memory temporarily after you unlock them with a passphrase. | Prevents repeated passphrase entry when connecting to multiple servers. | | ssh-add ~/.ssh/id_rsa | Loads a private key into the running SSH agent. | Makes automated workflows smoother, especially in development or CI/CD pipelines. |

docs.title: Day 008: Setting Up the Ansible Controller
docs.text: Today, I set up my first Ansible controller, allowing me to manage servers from a central point. The task involved preparing the jump_host for this role. The learning experience was interesting due to the nuanced reporting of Ansible, highlighting the difference between the community package and the core engine.

docs.title: The Task
docs.text: The goal was to create an Ansible controller for jump_host, requiring installation of version 4.7.0, using pip3 exclusively, and ensuring the ansible command is globally available for system use.

docs.title: My Step-by-Step Solution
docs.text: - The entire process was performed on the jump_host.

docs.title: Step 1: Install Ansible
docs.text:
• Using sudo to ensure the package was installed system-wide, not just for my user. 
    sudo pip3 install ansible==4.7.0

docs.title: Step 2: Verification
docs.text:
• After the installation, I ran a series of checks to confirm everything was correct. 
    # First, I checked the version as my regular 'thor' user
ansible --version

# Second, I checked where the command was installed from
which ansible

# Finally, I used pip to confirm the community package version
pip3 show ansible

docs.title: The Verification "Gotcha": ansible vs. ansible-core
docs.text:
- When I first ran ansible --version, I was surprised by the output: 

ansible [core 2.11.12] 
...
executable location = /usr/local/bin/ansible
...
I was looking for 4.7.0 but saw core 2.11.12. I learned that this is the expected behavior.

  • ansible (The Community Package): The version I installed, 4.7.0, refers to a large bundle of modules, plugins, and documentation. It's the whole product.
  • ansible-core (The Engine): The version shown in the output, 2.11.12, refers to the core engine that runs the playbooks. The ansible 4.7.0 package contains ansible-core 2.11.12.

My verification was actually a success: 1. The executable location of /usr/local/bin/ansible proved it was a global installation. 2. Running pip3 show ansible confirmed the community package version: 

Name: ansible
Version: 4.7.0
...

docs.title: Why Did I Do This? (The "What & Why")
docs.text: - Ansible: It's a leading configuration management tool used to automate application deployment, server provisioning, and general IT tasks. Its main advantages are its simplicity (using YAML for playbooks) and its "agentless" architecture, meaning it doesn't require special software to be installed on the managed servers—it just uses SSH. - Ansible Controller: The central machine that runs all automation. My jump_host now acts as the controller. - pip3: Python 3’s package installer. Installing Ansible with pip allows precise version control (e.g., ansible==4.7.0), which helps keep automation stable. - Globally Available: Installing with sudo puts Ansible in /usr/local/bin/ansible, so all users can run it. Without sudo, it would go to /home/thor/.local/bin/, limiting usage to one user.

docs.title: Common Pitfalls
docs.text: - Forgetting sudo: Without sudo, pip3 installs Ansible only for your user, not system-wide. - Wrong Version Syntax: Using = or no specifier installs the latest version instead of the required ansible==4.7.0. - Version Confusion: Not realizing the difference between ansible and ansible-core can make you think the installation failed, even when it succeeded.

docs.title: Exploring the Commands Used
docs.text: | Command | What actually happens internally | Why it matters in real environments | | | --------------------------------------------- | ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | sudo pip3 install ansible==4.7.0 | Uses pip3, the Python package manager, to download and install a specific version of Ansible from the Python Package Index (PyPI). The ==4.7.0 pins the installation to an exact version, meaning pip will not fetch the latest release but only that matching version. Using sudo installs it system-wide, typically inside /usr/local/lib/python3.x/site-packages/. | Version pinning is critical in automation. If your playbooks were tested with 4.7.0 and a newer release changes behavior, automation can break unexpectedly. Locking versions ensures consistency across environments. | | | python3 -m pip install ansible-core==2.11.5 | Installs ansible-core explicitly using Python’s module execution method. ansible-core contains the automation engine without bundled collections. Running pip through python3 -m guarantees that the package is installed using the exact Python interpreter you intend. | Prevents confusion when multiple Python versions are installed. In production systems, this avoids installing packages into the wrong interpreter path. | | | ansible --version | Displays the installed Ansible version, the location of its configuration file (ansible.cfg), module search paths, and the Python version it is running on. | Verifies not only version number but also which Python runtime and config path Ansible is using — useful when debugging unexpected behavior. | | | which ansible | Searches the directories listed in the PATH environment variable and returns the exact executable location being used. The PATH variable tells the shell where to look for commands. | Important when multiple Ansible installations exist. Confirms whether you are running the intended binary (for example, /usr/bin/ansible vs /usr/local/bin/ansible). | | | pip3 show ansible | Displays metadata about the installed package: version, install location, dependencies, and summary. | Confirms the exact version installed and whether pip recognizes it correctly. Helpful when troubleshooting version mismatches. | | | pip3 freeze | grep ansible | Shows installed packages with exact versions in requirements format. | Useful for exporting dependency lists to a requirements.txt file, ensuring reproducible setups. | | ansible-config dump | grep DEFAULT | Displays current configuration values used by Ansible. Configuration determines inventory location, remote user defaults, SSH settings, and more. | Helps confirm whether Ansible is reading the expected configuration file and using intended defaults. | | ansible-doc -l | Lists available Ansible modules. A module is a reusable unit of automation that performs a specific task, such as managing packages or files. | Useful for discovering built-in capabilities without browsing online documentation. | | | pip3 uninstall ansible | Removes the installed Ansible package from the Python environment. | Important when cleaning up conflicting versions or migrating to a different installation method. | | | python3 -m venv ansible-env | Creates a virtual environment — an isolated Python workspace with its own interpreter and package directory. | Best practice for avoiding system-wide dependency conflicts, especially when managing different Ansible versions for different projects. | |

docs.title: Day 009: Real-World Production Troubleshooting
docs.text:
Today’s task felt like a real production support scenario. A critical application was down because the database service failed. My role wasn’t to create something new, but to investigate, diagnose, and fix the issue.

It was a great exercise in methodical troubleshooting. I followed clues from general errors to detailed logs, tested different hypotheses, and finally found the root cause — which was deeper than it first appeared.

docs.title: The Task
docs.text: - The Nautilus application was down. The production support team had identified that the mariadb service was not running on the database server (stdb01). My task was to investigate the issue and bring the database service back online.

docs.title: My Troubleshooting Journey: A Step-by-Step Solution
docs.text: - My path to resolving this outage involved a multi-step investigation.

docs.title: Step 1: Initial Investigation
docs.text:
• First, I logged into the database server (peter@stdb01) and confirmed the problem using systemctl. 
    sudo systemctl status mariadb
# Output confirmed the service was "inactive (dead)"
  • My first attempt to fix it with a simple start command failed, which told me the problem was not a simple crash. 
    sudo systemctl start mariadb
# Output: Job for mariadb.service failed... See "journalctl -xeu mariadb.service" for details.

docs.title: Step 2: Digging into the Logs
docs.text:
• Following the error message's advice, I checked the detailed logs. 
    journalctl -xeu mariadb.service
    The logs were filled with "Operation not permitted" and "Failed to mount" errors. These were systemd errors, not MariaDB errors, pointing to a problem with the underlying server environment, likely file permissions or a missing resource.

docs.title: Step 3: Testing Hypotheses
docs.text:
• Hypothesis 1: Disk Space. My first thought was that the disk was full, as a database will refuse to start without space to write. 

    df -h
    This showed plenty of free space. Hypothesis was incorrect.

  • Hypothesis 2: Incorrect Directory Ownership. My next thought was that the data directory (/var/lib/mysql) was owned by the wrong user (e.g., root instead of mysql). 

    ls -ld /var/lib/mysql

docs.title: Step 4: Discovering the True Root Cause
docs.text:
• The previous command resulted in the ultimate clue: ls: cannot access '/var/lib/mysql': No such file or directory

  • The problem wasn't wrong permissions; the entire data directory was missing.

docs.title: Step 5: The Final Solution
docs.text:
• With the root cause identified, I executed the full recovery procedure.
  • Create the missing directory: 
    sudo mkdir /var/lib/mysql
  • Set the correct ownership so the mysql user could access it: 
    sudo chown mysql:mysql /var/lib/mysql
  • Initialize the database structure by running the installation script. This creates the necessary system tables in the new directory. 
    sudo mysql_install_db --user=mysql
  • Start the service. With all prerequisites in place, the service could finally start. 
    sudo systemctl start mariadb
  • Enable the service to ensure it starts after a reboot. 
    sudo systemctl enable mariadb
  • Final Verification. 
    sudo systemctl status mariadb
# Output now showed "active (running)"

docs.title: Why Did I Do This? (The "What & Why")
docs.text: - systemd and systemctl: systemd is the main service manager in modern Linux. systemctl is the tool to start, stop, enable, or check services — a core sysadmin skill. - journalctl: Lets you view detailed system logs. When systemctl status isn’t enough, journalctl helps find exact error messages. - Root Cause Analysis: This task taught me to go beyond fixing symptoms. The service was down, but the real problem was a missing directory. Restarting alone wouldn’t have solved it.

docs.title: Deep Dive: The Hierarchy of Troubleshooting
docs.text:
My process followed a logical hierarchy, moving from general to specific. 1. Confirm the problem: Is the service really down? (systemctl status) 2. Attempt a simple fix: Will a simple restart work? (systemctl start) 3. Gather more data: The simple fix failed, so why? (journalctl) 4. Form a hypothesis: Based on the logs (permission errors), I suspected an environmental issue. My first guess was disk space. 5. Test the hypothesis: Was the disk full? (df -h) No. 6. Refine the hypothesis: If not disk space, what else could cause permission errors? Incorrect file ownership. 7. Test the refined hypothesis: Who owns the data directory? (ls -ld) 8. Discover the root cause: The directory doesn't even exist. 9. Implement the full solution: Rebuild the environment (mkdir, chown, mysql_install_db) and then start the service.

This methodical process is key to solving complex issues efficiently.

docs.title: Common Pitfalls
docs.text: - Not Reading Error Messages: The start command failed but explicitly said to run journalctl. Ignoring this advice would leave you guessing. - Stopping at the First Clue: The journalctl logs mentioned "permission denied," which could lead one to only check chown. But the real problem was a level deeper: the directory itself was gone.

docs.title: Exploring the Commands Used
docs.text:
| Concept / Command | What is really happening inside the system | Why it matters during real outages | | ------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | systemd | The first user-space process started by the kernel (PID 1). It manages services using unit files, which define how a service starts, stops, and what it depends on. It keeps track of service states and supervises background processes. | Every production service depends on it for lifecycle management. If a database fails to start, systemd is the component reporting and controlling that state. | | systemctl | The command-line interface to communicate with systemd. It sends structured instructions like start, stop, or enable to service units. | This is the operational control panel for services. Knowing it is essential for any administrator handling backend systems. | | journalctl | Reads logs from the systemd journal. The journal is a centralized logging system that stores service logs along with metadata such as timestamps and process IDs. | When a service refuses to start, logs reveal why — permission denied, missing files, disk full, corrupted configuration, etc. | | Root Cause Analysis | A troubleshooting mindset where you identify the underlying reason for a failure instead of only restoring temporary functionality. | Prevents repeated incidents. Fixing only the symptom results in recurring downtime. |

Command What it actually checks or modifies internally Why it becomes important sudo systemctl status mariadb Queries systemd for the current state of the MariaDB service. It shows whether it is active, inactive, or failed, along with recent log messages. First diagnostic step when a database is down. It confirms whether the problem is startup failure or runtime crash. sudo systemctl start mariadb Instructs systemd to execute the MariaDB service unit file, which launches the database daemon (mysqld). Attempts recovery after configuration or environment correction. sudo systemctl enable mariadb Creates boot-time symbolic links so MariaDB starts automatically after reboot. Ensures database availability across server restarts. journalctl -xeu mariadb.service Filters journal logs specifically for the MariaDB unit. -u selects the service, -e jumps to the latest entries, and -x adds contextual explanation. Reveals precise startup errors, such as “data directory not found” or “permission denied.” df -h Displays filesystem disk usage. The -h option presents sizes in human-readable format (MB, GB). If the disk is full, MariaDB cannot write logs or temporary files, and startup fails. Storage issues are a common hidden cause. ls -ld /var/lib/mysql Shows details about the directory itself, including ownership and permissions. The -d flag ensures information about the directory rather than its contents. MariaDB requires its data directory to be owned by the mysql user. Incorrect ownership prevents startup. sudo mkdir /var/lib/mysql Creates the required directory if missing. If the directory does not exist, the database cannot initialize or store data files. sudo chown -R mysql:mysql /var/lib/mysql Recursively sets ownership to the mysql user and group. Recursive (-R) means all subdirectories and files are updated. Ensures the database daemon has permission to read and write its data files. sudo mysql_install_db --user=mysql Initializes an empty data directory by creating system tables required by MariaDB (like user privilege tables). Necessary when the data directory is newly created or corrupted. Without initialization, the database engine has nothing to load.

docs.title: Day 010: Automating Backups with a Bash Script
docs.text: Today I was tasked with creating a bash script to automate website backup, a task that required preparing the server environment for seamless automation. Successful automation involves setting prerequisites and writing the script, which is crucial for a successful automation. Today I learned that a strong foundation is essential for successful automation.

docs.title: The Task
docs.text:
I needed to create a bash script called news_backup.sh on App Server 2 to handle a multi-step backup. Requirements:

  1. Script location → /scripts directory.
  2. Backup website files → /var/www/html/news into a .zip archive.
  3. Archive name → xfusioncorp_news.zip, saved locally in /backup.
  4. Copy archive → Transfer it to the Nautilus Backup Server into /backup.
  5. Password-less execution → My user (steve) must run it without prompts.
  6. Prerequisite → zip utility must be installed manually before running the script.
  7. Restriction → No sudo allowed inside the script.

docs.title: My Step-by-Step Solution
docs.text: - I broke my approach into two distinct phases: preparing the environment and then writing the script.

docs.title: Part 1: The Critical Prerequisite Setup
docs.text:
- I performed these one-time setup steps on App Server 2 as the steve user.

  1. Install zip: The task required the zip utility for archiving. 

    sudo yum install -y zip

  2. Create and Own Directories: The script needed a home (/scripts) and a place to store backups (/backup). I created them with sudo and then immediately changed their ownership to my user, steve. This was a key step to ensure my script could write to these locations without needing sudo. 

    sudo mkdir -p /scripts /backup
sudo chown steve:steve /scripts /backup

  3. Establish Password-less SSH: This was the most important prerequisite. To allow my script to copy a file to the backup server automatically, I set up SSH key-based authentication.

    • First, I generated a key pair for my user on App Server 2: 
      ssh-keygen -t rsa
# I pressed Enter for all prompts to accept defaults and set no passphrase.
    • Next, I used the ssh-copy-id utility to send my public key to the Nautilus Backup Server. I had to enter the backup server user's (clint) password one last time to authorize this. 
      ssh-copy-id clint@stbkp01
    • Finally, I tested the connection to make sure it was truly password-less. 
      ssh clint@stbkp01
# It logged me in instantly. Success! I typed 'exit' to return.

docs.title: Part 2: Writing the Backup Script
docs.text:
- With the environment fully prepared, I was ready to write the script.

  1. Create and Edit the Script: I created an empty, executable file in the correct location. 

    touch /scripts/news_backup.sh
chmod +x /scripts/news_backup.sh
vi /scripts/news_backup.sh

  2. The Script Content: I added the following code into the file. I made sure to add comments to explain what each part of the script does. 

    #!/bin/bash

# This script creates a zip archive of the website directory,
# saves it to a local backup folder, and then securely copies
# it to a remote backup server.

# Step 1: Create a recursive zip archive of the website files.
# The archive is saved to the /backup directory.
zip -r /backup/xfusioncorp_news.zip /var/www/html/news

# Step 2: Copy the created archive to the backup server.
# This scp command works without a password because of the
# prerequisite SSH key setup.
scp /backup/xfusioncorp_news.zip clint@stbkp01:/backup/

  3. Execution and Verification: After saving the script, I ran it and verified its success at each stage. 

    # Execute the script
/scripts/news_backup.sh

# Verify the local backup was created
ls -l /backup/xfusioncorp_news.zip

# Verify the remote backup was copied successfully
ssh clint@stbkp01 "ls -l /backup/xfusioncorp_news.zip"
    Both verification commands showed the xfusioncorp_news.zip file, confirming my script had worked perfectly.

docs.title: Why Did I Do This? (The "What & Why")
docs.text: - Bash Scripting: This is the universal language for automation on Linux. By writing a script, I created a repeatable, reliable process that eliminates the chance of human error that comes with typing commands manually. - zip Command: Compresses files into a single archive. Using -r ensures all contents of /var/www/html/news are included, making storage and transfer easier. - scp (Secure Copy): Copies files between servers securely over SSH. It’s the standard tool for simple, safe file transfers.

docs.title: Deep Dive: Why Password-less SSH is Non-Negotiable for Automation
docs.text:
Automation must run without human intervention — a script that stops for a password is broken.

  • Public Key Authentication → The industry-standard solution.
  • The Trust Relationship → Using ssh-copy-id, I placed a “public lock” from App Server 2 onto the Backup Server.
  • The Secure Handshake → When scp runs, App Server 2 proves its identity using its private key.
  • Seamless Execution → The Backup Server verifies it and allows the file transfer instantly, no password needed.

This is how tools like Ansible, Jenkins, and scripts can manage servers automatically.

docs.title: Common Pitfalls
docs.text: - Forgetting to Install zip: The script would fail immediately at the zip command. - Incorrect Permissions: Without chown on /scripts and /backup, steve couldn’t create the script or archive, causing “Permission denied” errors. - Skipping the SSH Key Setup: Without keys, scp would stop and ask for a password, breaking automation. - Using sudo in the Script: Proper ownership and permissions are safer and cleaner than embedding sudo.

docs.title: Exploring the Commands Used
docs.text: | Command | What actually happens inside the system | Why it matters in real work | | -------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | sudo yum install -y zip | Uses the yum package manager to download and install the zip utility from configured repositories. The package manager resolves dependencies automatically. The -y flag auto-confirms prompts. | Many minimal servers don’t include archive tools by default. Installing zip allows you to compress logs, backups, or deployment packages before transfer. | | sudo mkdir -p /path | Creates a directory. The -p option tells the system to create parent directories if they do not already exist, and it avoids throwing an error if the directory already exists. | Useful in automation scripts. Instead of checking whether a directory exists first, -p makes the command idempotent — meaning it can run multiple times without breaking. | | sudo chown user:group /path | Changes file ownership. Linux tracks ownership using numeric user ID (UID) and group ID (GID). This command updates those metadata fields in the inode, which is the filesystem structure storing file information. | Services like web servers or databases often run under specific users. If ownership is wrong, the service cannot read or write files. | | chgrp group /path | Changes only the group ownership while keeping the user owner unchanged. | Helpful when adjusting shared access without altering primary ownership. | | ssh-keygen -t rsa | Generates an asymmetric key pair (private and public key). RSA is a cryptographic algorithm based on prime number factorization. The private key stays on your machine; the public key can be shared. | Enables secure, passwordless authentication. Instead of sending a password, identity is proven using cryptographic signatures. | | ssh-copy-id user@host | Logs into the remote server and appends your public key to ~/.ssh/authorized_keys on that host. It also ensures directory and file permissions are correct. | Eliminates the need to manually edit the remote file and reduces common permission mistakes that break key authentication. | | chmod +x /path/to/script.sh | Adds the execute permission bit to the file. Linux requires the execute flag to treat a file as a runnable program. Without it, even a valid script cannot be executed. | Essential when deploying automation scripts or custom tools. | | zip -r archive.zip directory_to_zip | Recursively (-r) compresses a directory and its contents into a single archive file. Compression reduces file size using algorithms that remove redundant data patterns. | Used when packaging project directories for backup, sharing, or deployment. | | unzip archive.zip | Extracts compressed contents back into files and directories. | Required on the receiving side of file transfers. | | scp source_file user@host:/destination | Uses the SSH protocol to securely copy files between systems. Data is encrypted during transfer using SSH’s encryption layer. | Quick and secure way to deploy configuration files, backups, or scripts to remote servers. | | rsync -avz source/ user@host:/destination/ | Synchronizes files efficiently. -a preserves metadata, -v shows progress, -z compresses during transfer. Unlike scp, it transfers only differences between source and destination. | More efficient for large deployments or repeated updates, especially when only a few files change. |

docs.title: Day 011: Deploying a Java Application on Tomcat
docs.text: Today's task involved deploying a Java application, where I set up the Apache Tomcat server, configured it, and deployed a pre-packaged web application. The deployment process included preparing the destination server, ensuring secure transfer, and executing the deployment, highlighting the multi-phase nature of application deployment.

docs.title: The Task
docs.text: My objective was to deploy a Java web application on App Server 3. The process involved several specific requirements: 1. Install the Apache Tomcat application server. 2. Configure Tomcat to run on port 8084 instead of its default 8080. 3. Copy a pre-built application file, ROOT.war, from the /tmp directory on the Jump host. 4. Deploy this .war file to the Tomcat server. 5. Verify that the application was accessible directly at the base URL (e.g., http://stapp03:8084).

docs.title: My Step-by-Step Solution
docs.text: I broke my solution into three logical phases to ensure a smooth and error-free deployment.

docs.title: Phase 1: Installing and Configuring Tomcat on App Server 3
docs.text:
First, I prepared the destination server.

  1. Connect and Install: I logged into App Server 3 (banner@stapp03) and used yum to install the Tomcat package. 

    sudo yum install -y tomcat

  2. Configure the Port: This was a critical configuration change. I edited Tomcat's main configuration file, server.xml, with vi. 

    sudo vi /etc/tomcat/server.xml

    Inside the file, I searched for the Connector tag and changed its port attribute from 8080 to 8084.

  3. Start and Enable the Service: Finally, I started the Tomcat service and enabled it to ensure it would restart automatically after a reboot.
